caseProcess.description: The Vandalia Tax Bureau conducted a preliminary investigation into the tax arrears of the defendant, T. Bennett, upon suspicion of evading tax recovery for the year 2022.
Following the initial findings, detention measures were enforced to prevent flight risk and tampering with evidence.
T. Bennett was formally detained under criminal custody upon further evidence corroborating the tax evasion allegations.
Arrest warrant was issued and executed on T. Bennett after substantial evidence was reviewed by the Farmington, Vandalia, Procuratorate.

criminalFacts.crimeName: Crime of Evading Tax Arrears Recovery

details.behavior: T. Bennett transferred significant assets to her brotherâ€™s company in a deliberate attempt to avoid tax recovery measures.
details.evidence: Bank statements showing transfers amounting to $120,000, testimony from the brother, and emails outlining the transfer process.

details.behavior: The defendant falsified accounts and underreported her consultancy income to evade taxes.
details.evidence: Financial audit report detailing discrepancies, written confessions from two employees, and altered balance sheets recovered from her office.

details.behavior: T. Bennett sold a high-value property located at 123 Main Street, Vandalia, without reporting the transaction to the tax authorities.
details.evidence: Property sales contract, testimony from the buyer, and email communication regarding the sale.

judgmentResult.crimeName: Crime of Evading Tax Arrears Recovery
judgmentResult.sentence: 5 years imprisonment and a fine of $300,000.
judgmentResult.sentencingConsiderations: The significant amount of tax owed, the premeditated nature of the evasion, and lack of remorse displayed by the defendant were considered in the sentencing.
